+patataboy Look, we really need to establish something here:

I am talking about race because this issue is purely about race. *“Hafu” is 
a purely racial label.* It says nothing about a person's cultural behaviour 
in Japan.

The Hafu film website: “Hafu highlights the *genetic makeup* of half 
Japanese people, emphasizing the *existence of foreign blood*.”

Wikipedia: “The word hafu is used…to refer to somebody who is *biracial*”

There is no mention of culture.

Just because you are "hafu", it doesn't mean that you positively act in a 
way that is incompatible with Japanese society. Our frustration is not that 
people won't let us turn Japan into the cultural mirror image of America or 
France or China. We are frustrated because despite doing our best to get 
along as ordinary Japanese citizens, we still get singled out as weird 
aliens *just because we are seen as racially different*. 

Nishikura says this: “*Based on the way I look*, where do you think I’m 
from?” She’s saying that there is an unspoken agreement where you have to 
“look” Japanese in order to be seen as a normal human being in Japan. She 
is talking about the racial requirement. 

I think race is a stupid concept. It’s pseudoscience and doesn’t have a 
definition that works. But the “hafu” issue is one of race, so yes, I will 
talk about race. My argument is that *we should not measure people’s 
legitimacy as citizens by their race or ancestry*. Sure, prejudice may be 
an obvious and ineradicable part of life, as you say, but it can be 
identified and reduced too. The worst response is to deny that it's there, 
or to shrug it off and say that its victims should simply cater to the 
laziness of its perpetrators. 

Now, if you want to talk about people who positively act in a way that is 
culturally incompatible, then we can do so if you really want. But we need 
to be clear that that is a separate issue.

+patataboy I can see how the evolution of Japanese language and social 
interaction might trouble some people. Nevertheless, I think we agree that 
treating “hafu” as outsiders is not going to make everyone more socially 
hesitant or better at kanji.

And if you consider Japan to be more xenophobic than racist, I can live 
with that. 

I was going to address your other point, but I find it a little patronising 
to be told that people like me must “show that they can be as Japanese as 
everyone else”, and that “trust is something you fight to get, not 
something you beg for.” I am not begging for people’s trust or approval. I 
simply resent being seen as a zoo animal in my own country, and I think 
that if Japan can be made less racist - sorry, xenophobic - than it is now, 
then it will be better than any kind of wistful romanticism about the good 
old days of so-called homogeneity. 

Why is it worth supporting a façade of homogeneity, anyway? You say that 
homogeneity makes Japan safer, preventing the “uncontrolled, unwanted and 
non-assimilated immigration” of other nations. But consider this:

1. “Hafu” are not an immigrant group; they are usually citizens by 
birthright. 
 
2. Japan was ranked 8th in the 2014 Global Peace Index (out of 162), but 
Australia was 15th, Ireland 13th, Canada 7th, and New Zealand 4th. Racial 
pluralism isn’t inherently dangerous; it depends on how it is managed. A 
great way to mismanage it is to alienate minorities by promoting the idea 
of a singular, homogenous racial group.

3. “Foreign races” commit *less* crime per capita in Japan than the 
“racially Japanese”. 

4. You’ve just implied that “hafu” Japanese are inherent troublemakers. Can 
you demonstrate this?  

Anyway, what more am I supposed to do to prove to my 127 million 
compatriots that I am "as Japanese as everyone else" (particularly since 
you say that racial purity is a key part of what makes Japan so wonderfully 
Japanese)? The “hafu” who “succeed” are paraded as models and TV 
personalities not necessarily because they “embraced their Japanese culture 
and heritage” as you suggested, but rather because that is how “hafu” are 
seen in Japan: not as ordinary people, but as exotic creatures from 
elsewhere.  It is natural human behaviour to mimic and to fit in, so it is 
not as though “hafu” Japanese have never tried to be good citizens. They do 
not start life thinking that they must act differently – they learn that 
their compatriots see them that way by default, no matter how “Japanese” 
they are in their actions.

So instead of singling out racially different strangers and ordering them 
to work for your trust, I say that it’s more important to ask what right 
you have to hold such an attitude in the first place. What say you?

comments.text:
+patataboy In my country (Japan), there probably are many “half African or 
half Arab” people, as you put it. Are they “completely assimilated”? I 
don’t know what that question means. What does it mean to be “assimilated”, 
in your view? How would you measure that?

In any case, this popular depiction of Japan as a pure, unchanging society 
under threat from foreign influence is a complete myth. 

Japan doesn’t have a history of ethnic homogeneity. The early population is 
thought to have been a mixture of Jōmon migrants from Austronesia, and of 
the Yayoi who arrived later from central Asia. Many self-identifying 
members of indigenous communities (in northern Japan and in the Ryūkyū 
islands, for example) still regard themselves as ethnically separate. 
Racial diversity doesn’t have to resemble the rainbow of colours depicted 
in multiculturalism advertisements. 

There is also much more to a person’s cultural identity than race and 
nationality. Two people might share Japanese nationality, but be of 
different genders, religions, regional cultures, social classes, language 
groups, professional industries, political ideologies, and so on. It is 
this to which I was referring when I spoke of “cultural groups”: even 
before you account for external influences, the Japanese population is 
already very culturally diverse. Race is only one of many ways in which 
people can differ.

This also shows why Japanese culture has been *constantly* changing – even 
during the Edo isolation. Cultural shifts result from the interactions 
between individuals, who are all different. Change is therefore inevitable.

So it’s no good asking why we “try so hard to change” Japan. It’s a matter 
of asking what kind of change we want to see: do we so value the myth of 
Japanese homogeneity that we are willing to build a society on racist 
principles? Or are we going to move towards a society that doesn’t exclude 
people for how they look and where their parents are from?

captions.text:
Based on the way I look,
where do you think I'm from?
India?
Mexico?
How about Italy?
What about Kyrgyzstan?

These are some of the places
people think I'm from.

What I actually am is half Japanese
and half Irish American.

There is a term commonly used
to identify people like myself,
and that is "hafu".
In my day-to-day experience in Japan,

people are often surprised
to learn that I am hafu.
Strangers will come up to me and say,
"Okuni wa doko desuka?" --
What country are you from?

When they learn
my last name is Nishikura,

the next question usually is:
"Nihonjin to kekkon sarete masuka?" --
Are you married to a Japanese?

I often reply with:
No, my father is Japanese. --
"Jitsuwa otousan ga Nihonjin desu."

But what I really want to say is:
It's because I'm Japanese.

I'm very fortunate, in that
I come from a loving family

that had the means
to give me the opportunity

to spend my summers
in the United States.

So, I grew up
between two different worlds.

In Japan, I remember going
to the local matsuris, the festivals,

and trying my darnedest
to scoop up that goldfish

with that paper scoop
but always failing.

And, in America, I remember going to
the local shopping mall

and being in awe of how the stores
just stretched out for miles.
For a young girl, it was paradise.

But wherever I went, once I was beyond
the comfort of my home or family,
I always felt like I didn't quite fit in.

I wanted to belong, which I think
is a natural human desire.

In Japan, I wish my teachers
at my Japanese elementary school

wouldn't single me out
for being able to speak English.

And, in America,
I wish I had blonde pigtails

like the girls in
my grandmother's neighborhood.

While I was lucky
to have never been picked on in school,

I know that there are
those of us who have.

Simply, whether innocent
or malicious intent,

simply by the way somebody
says something to us or looks at us,

we are acutely reminded that
we are not like those around us,
that we don't belong.

And, sometimes, that desire
to belong is so great

that we are willing to hide or change
that part of us that is different.

But it's not as simple
as buying a new wardrobe
to fit in with the cool kids.

Denying who we are,
even one part of us,

creates the suffocating feeling,
like we're not good enough.

Even today, I catch
a glimpse of myself in the mirror

of a restaurant where I'm eating
with my relatives,
and I go, "Wow, I look so different.
How is it that I am related?
Do I even belong here?"
But then a moment later, I am moved.

Moved by the fact,
that despite their differences,
both cultural and racial,
my parents found love.

And those differences
were once so great

that my grandparents
were on opposite sides of a war.

Knowing the value of respecting
and loving both cultures,

my parents raised me to believe
that I was both Japanese and American.
However, in Japan in particular,

society has trouble
reflecting that back to me.

People don't even often recognize me
as being half Japanese;
they just see me as a foreigner.

Now, some might say
this is understandable

with only 2% of the population
in Japan being not Japanese,

and there being
few ethic minorities here.

But as somebody who has grown up here,
and is Japanese by birth,
why is it so hard to be recognized as one?
So, what does it mean to be Japanese?

It seems like there's
this unspoken definition.

One must look Japanese,
speak Japanese,

and abide by all its customs
and traditions.

And, if someone can't check off each box,
a hundred percent,
then he or she is not Japanese.

But people like me are becoming
more and more common every day.

Today, 1 in 18 marriages
is an international union,

and, as a result, 1 in 49 babies
are born between such couples.
That is over 20,000 hafus a year.

With such changing demographics,
I think the current understanding

of what it means to be Japanese
needs to change.
[A new definition of Japanese]

The definition of Japanese
needs to expand to include hafus.

"Konna kao demo Nihonjin
de arieru shakai ni nattehoshii." --

Maybe you can look like me
and sound like me, and still be Japanese.

As a film maker, exploring these questions
came naturally to me
through the lens of a camera.

So, it began in film school,
where I made short movies
about my personal identity and my family,

to upon graduating,
where I started producing videos

for organizations
that fight racial prejudice
and foster multi-cultural understanding.
All of which leads to this moment now,
where, through the hafu project,
I met three young hafu women like myself,

and together we came
to make a feature length film.

Through five stories filmed over a year,
we asked these very questions:

What does it mean to be hafu
and what does it mean to be Japanese?

(Video) Woman: He was started
to be called names:

"You are not Japanese,
you are Eigo-jin."
Boy: I was bullied every day.

[What does it mean to be
mixed-race in Japan?]

Man: I stuck out wherever I was
and people treated me differently.

I thought,
just treat me normally!

Talk to me just as
you would to anyone else!
Woman: I really believed I was Japanese.

So suddenly I felt like
I didn't belong anywhere.

When you're younger,
you don't want to be different,
you want to be like everybody else.
Man: I feel disconnected from Japan.

[Each year over 20,000
half-Japanese babies are born]
Woman: I feel like Japan is changing.

Everyday, you see these little,
half-Japanese children running around.

Man: I discovered that there were many
people that had similar backgrounds.

Woman: He realized that he didn't
have to try to become someone
that everybody else expects him to be.

Man: There's prejudice
and racism wherever you go.

I want to connect with
people who can see me for me.

Woman: Instead of disliking
what's different
if we embrace and learn from it

then Japan will have
such a bright future.

[SOPHIA
Australia x Japan]

[EDWARD
Venezuela x Japan]

[FUSAE
Korea x Japan]

[OI FAMILY
Mexico x Japan]

[DAVID
Ghana x Japan]
[Japan is Changing]
[HAFU]

[Meet the new generation
of mixed Japanese]
(Applause)

MN: Since we began filming,
the response has been tremendous.

Hafus and their families write to us
from all corners of the globe
offering their support and encouragement.

To me, this is a testament that the parts
of us that feels unrecognized
wants our stories to be heard.

The film was completed in April
and is now screening worldwide.

None of us hafus chose
to be born this way.
However, having come from two parents

of different cultures
or different phenotypes,
by our mere presence,

we've been given an opportunity
to start this conversation

about the labels that
society places on all of us.
I believe these labels of separation

are what leads to exclusion,
discrimination, conflict, and even war.

Ultimately, I think it's not just about
being recognized as part of Japan,
I think what we're really seeking

is to be seen authentically
in our entirety,

for the parts of us that is Japanese
and the parts of us that is not.

What I have come to understand is that
it is up to each and every one of us

to decide for ourselves
who we are

and not to be confined by the boundaries
that seek to define us or exclude us.

And, in that act of knowing
who we are and accepting it,

we allow others to know it is okay
for us to be that way as well.
My name is Nishikura Megumi.

With this name and this face,
I am Japanese, American, and hafu.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Explorations into being Hafu: Megumi Nishikura at TEDxKyoto 2013
